pages.title: Purpose
pages.text: The power reactor generates massive amounts of RF from nuclear fission. It uses fuel rods loaded into empty fuel rod blocks. $(bold)Always$() ensure cooling is active before inserting fuel.

pages.title: Layer 1 (Bottom - Coolant)
pages.text: The bottom layer is mostly air with a single power_reactor_port (0) in the center. Pump coolant in here to establish your cooling loop. The reactor will $(bold)overheat and fail$() without active cooling.

pages.title: Layer 2 & 3 (Core)
pages.text: The main fission chamber. Layer 2 has a central reaction_chamber (H); Layer 3 swaps the center for the power_reactor_interface (I). Both layers use control_rods (R) and reactor_casing (C) around the core.

pages.title: Layer 4 (Top - Fuel Loading)
pages.text: Four empty_fuel_rods (E) positioned around the reactor top. Right-click each with crusty_chunks:fuel_rod to load fuel. You'll need $(bold)4-5 fuel rods per empty slot$() to start the reaction.

pages.title: Fuel Management
pages.text: Hold crusty_chunks:fuel_rod in hand and right-click an empty_fuel_rod block (E). Each slot requires 4-5 rods to initialize. Once loaded, the reactor becomes active and begins generating continuous power.

pages.title: Multiblock Guide
pages.text: The power reactor is a 7x7x4 structure. Layer 4 is the top (fuel ports). Layers 2-3 form the core fission chamber. Layer 1 is the bottom (coolant input). See the next page for the full multiblock visualization.

pages.name: Power Reactor (7x7x4)
pages.text: Full 7x7x4 layout shown top->bottom: fuel ports (E), interface (I), reaction core (H), and coolant port (0).
